7.18.25  11:33 am   sometimes your response to a question doesn't seem to attempt to answer the question, but often from a reader point of view it makes for a better reading experience than if you did just answer the question. which makes me wonder if the whole "q&a" premise of this page is actually just a cover up and this is actually more of a "make a prompt for bill wurtz to come up with a fun response" type deal (but i realize that's just one of many scenarios). but now that i think about it that might be true for in-person q&a's and interviews as well. does any of this make sense

7.18.25  5:51 am   Hey Bill! I am trying to write my own music and Im wondering what you would recommend I focus on learning next. I'm comfortable with 7th chords and I finally understand the difference between dominant 7s vs. Major and minor 7s. I know the major scale (do re me fa so la ti do), and I can use the chords/scale degrees (I ii iii IV V vi vii) to build progressions..

But I feel like when I write, I keep playing octaves and a 5th on the left hand and major or minor triads on the right. Now that I learned all major, minor and 7th chords in root position, everything I play as a roman numeral progression sounds so similar (and not very great since I don't know my inversions yet) I'm vaguely comfortable using diminished/augmented chords or some passing chords here and there and I'm familiar with raising the bass note a whole step up for a jazzy slash chord at the very end of a phrase... But other than a few things like that, my jazz vocabulary is pretty limited and I can't seem to figure out how you do all these complex key modulations. There has to be a better way than aimlessly watching a bunch of jazz music theory videos on YouTube, right? Should I grind out the inversions? Should I learn how to write in minor keys? If you have a textbook I could read or anything to point me in tne right direction, I'd really appreciate your help!

7.18.25  4:48 am   How come you can say you're doing something "in practice" to mean actually doing the thing, but you can also say you're "practicing", meaning you're improving before actually doing the thing. Is that not confusing?
